title: 110_hr2884
content: The Act may be cited as the "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act". It includes a provision for fingerprints for members of the armed forces. The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to use fingerprints provided by individuals enlisting in the Armed Forces to fulfill naturalization application requirements under certain conditions. The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" permits the Secretary of Homeland Security to utilize fingerprints from Armed Forces enlistees for naturalization applications if deemed sufficient. Individuals can submit new fingerprints for faster processing if advised by the Secretary. Cooperation with the Secretary of Defense is required for determining the format. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, determines acceptable fingerprint formats for naturalization applications. The Secretary of Defense provides fingerprints to the Secretary of Homeland Security without charge and cooperates to fulfill naturalization requirements. SEC. 3. The Secretary of Homeland Security must update relevant websites within 30 days of any changes to naturalization regulations. It is recommended that application forms be updated within 180 days. SEC. 4. Reports are required. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report on the adjudication process for naturalization applications within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will cover the entire process from application submission to final decision, including the methods and effectiveness of the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense in handling applications. The Comptroller General will study the implementation of the Act by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense, focusing on technology to improve naturalization for Armed Forces members. A report must be submitted within 180 days of the study. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the appropriate congressional committees on recommendations for improving the implementation of the Act by the Secretary of Homeland Security or the Secretary of Defense. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The House of Representatives passed the Act on November 6, 2007. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
